question: 2 (b)
sols_html:
As the ODE is separable, we can re-express with the differentials separated:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (x^2+1) dx = (t^2+1) dt\end{aligned}\]

which can be integrated to yield

\[\begin{aligned} \int (x^2+1) dx = \frac{x^3}{3} + x = \int (t^2+1) dt = \frac{t^3}{3} + t + C\end{aligned}\]

We merge the two integration constants to C. From our initial condition that \(x(0) = -1\) we obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \frac{(-1)^3}{3} - 1 = \frac{0^3}{3} + 0 + C\end{aligned}\]

and hence C = -4/3. Left in implicit form the solution reads

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{x^3}{3} + x = \frac{t^3}{3} + t - \frac{4}{3}\end{aligned}\]

statement_html:
Solve

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dx}{dt} = \frac{t^2+1}{x^2+1}, \quad x(0) = -1.\end{aligned}\]

You may leave your result in implicit form.
